and liberal student clubs which will

since their innovation of such
affairs ~9. These meetings

Boone To Attend

Lectures In Schooler Foundation

Marshall Boone, former track
star of Stanford University, an
outstanding man in official track
circles, who is connected with
the A. A. U. and the Intercollegiate Track Association will be
present at the meeting.
Mr.
Boone will have with him a motion picture projector with which
he will show pictures of many
track stars with whom he is well
acquainted, performing in intercollegiate events and the last
Olympics.
All candidates for track must
attend this meeting, and will
have to fill out- caicfs regarding
equipment and the specific event
for which they desire to try out.
The first-comers will receive the
choice of the equipment during
the initial spring practice of the
season. The date of this practice
will be announced at the meeting". Those not attending the
meeting will not receive any
equipment.

Dr. Kalaw ,has lectured before
many American universities this
month. • He will come to the Hopkins University of the Schouler
Foundation. In March, 1908, Dr.
James Schouler, of Boston, who
had lectured in this University annually since 1891, announced his
purpose to found a lecturship in the
University, which is known as the
James Schouler Lecturship of History and Political Science.
The donor expressed the wish
"that such lectures be given annually if possible, . an(l that persons of

and routine of the meets and
practices.

try out for the team. Chassin,

Jung, captain of this year's team,
comprise the group of veterans
remaining from last year.

Is Student Of Government

The Filippino educator is well
versed in the field of the demanq of
his native land for freedom. He is
head of the Department of Political
Science and "is one of the foremost
students of Government in the
Philippines," according to Dr. Stephen P. Duggan, director of the Institute of International Education.
He has received most of his college education in this country. In
1915, he received his L.L.B. from
the Georgetown University; studied
at the George Washington Univer,
sity, and was visiting professor at
the University of Michigan.
In 1918, Dr. Kalaw was editor of
th Manila Tim,.es. He has written
numerous books on the Government
of the Philippines and the demand
for its independence. Some of these
are "The Case for the Filipinos"
and "Self Government in · the
Philippines."

FROM ALL appearances, the
new plan for junior and seniors,
which goes into effect in October
at the Johns Hopkins University,
will attach to the bachelor of arts
degree a real value for one, if not
the chief reason, that the upperclassman will be required in the
future to do a type of researcJi
work in his major subject and will
be required to display a comprehen-

Arthur Lee Kinsolving, rector
at Old Trinity Church in Boston,
will be the speaker at the next
meeting of the University Supper Club, Tuesday, February 32,
at 6 P. M.
Kinsolving is the son of Arthur B. Kinsolving, Pastor of
Old St. Paul's Church in Baltimore, and isa graduate of Amherst. He has just recently been
given his charge at Trinity,
whjch is the church made famous by Phillips Brooks, one of

its relation to allied subjects.
Doubtless, the plan, finally promulgated, after detailed study, in
December, 1931, will serve to raise
the standard of the A.B. school at
Homewood and to weed out those
undergraduates who attend college
to just "take courses." It will
call upon greater concentration
in and thought to a particular field.
It will necessitate the r.etaining o~
knowledge acquired throughout two
full years, to be used at the completion of the senior year in the
comprehensive examination which
is to be the outstanding determining
factor for graduation.
THOUGH NO definite decision
has been reached, it is believed that
the three groups-social scienc~
natural science, language and litera(Continued pn page 2, col. 6)

Announcement of the requirements for graduation under the
New Plan was made last week by
Dean E. W. Berry, of the College
of Arts and Sciences. These requirements will affect all candidates
for the A.B. degree at the Hopkins.
It will be recalled that under the
New Plan, which is to be inaugurated next fall, a Sophomore, after
proving to the Bo,ard of Collegiate
Studies that he is qualified to remain in the College, must arrange
his courses in one of three groups:
the Social Science, Natural Science,
or Literature and Language. However, this applies ol.'ily to candidates
for the A.B. who have completed
the regular collegiate requirements
for tllillfllt and second years of
~~ - --~ --- ___
Groups Of Related Subjects

Each of the three groups is made
up of departments of related subjects. The Social Science Group
incudes the subjects of History,
_)olitical Economy, Political Science,
History of Philosophy, Ethics, and
Education; the Natural Sciences
comprise Biology, Chemistry, Geology, Mathematics, Physics, Psychology, and Logic; and the Literature and Language Group is made
up of the subjects of English,
Fren_ch, German, Italian, Spanish,
Latin, Greek, Hebrew, Sanskrit, and
Archaeology.
The purpose of
grouping related subjects into the
one unit, it was stated by Dr. W. S.
Holt, associate in American History, and Chairman of the Social
Science Group, is that the student's
knowledge may not be limited to the
specific subject in which he is interested, but that he may have a
general acquaintance with related·
fields of knowledge. In the Social
Science Group, one must prove his
familiarity with all the subjects in
the Group, at least generally, besides fulfilling his obligations to his
particular subject.
Before a student in the Social
Science Group may graduate, he
must take a comprehensive examination on the following points, which
are given as they will apear in the
1932-33 University Catalogue:
Group Requirements

A knowledge of economic
geography.
A knowledge of international
problems and organization in
modern times.
A knowledge of the principal
governments of the world, and
how they function.
An acquaintance with the more
important political and economic
theories of the past and present,
and of their historical setting.
A knowledge of modern European history.
A knowledge of the history of
the United States.
An appreciation of the methods of the social sciences.

A knowledge of the characteristics forms of the economic systems of the past ad present, of
the causes and consequences of
the economic development of the
United States.
The nature of this comprehensive
examination is ·an outline specifically indicating the points which the
student is to find out by research,
and he will be allowed four weeks
in which to complete the problem.
The first comprehensive will be
given in May, 1933.
It was
emphasised by Dr. Holt that these
reqttirements are those of the
Group alone. Each Department in
the Group may make its own specifications as to the knowledge of the
student, and may require that he
· ~.kt:i.mvf~dg~ ;
·
courses, research, reading, or by
any other method which it desires.
As far as the Group is concerned, it
makes no difference how the student
prepares for his comprehensive
exam, Dr. Holt declared. Furthermore, the exam, which is given each
year, may be taken regardless of
the number of years the student has
been in the college. Thus, especially industrious ones may graduate
after their Junior year.
Personal Research

This conception of the comprehensive examination is identical
with the idea of the term paper,
recently set forth by a local college,
insofar as it permits the student to
carry on a research of his subject on
his own account. The department
may require him to satisfy its
specifications either by examination
or any other means it may determine upon. He will be assigned to
a faculty adviser who will be able
to direct his method of approach to
the completion of his work.
A plan whereby classes would be
suspended for given periods of
possibly a month in duration, dur·
·
mg
wh.1c h time
t h e stu d ent wou ld
carry out a program of reading on
a subject assigned him and turn in
a report on his work, is under consideration by the Social Science
Group, Dr. Holt stated. He regards as a possible impediment to
the smoothness of this plan, however, the fact that instructors in all
the Groups may not be willing to
suspend their classes at the same
time, if at all. Having to attend any
classes would disturb an uninterrupted reading period and cause it
to lose its effectiveness, it is believed. It is hoped, however, that an
arrangement may be made for the
effecting of the idea.
The Natural Science Group, of
which Dr. Gordon F. Whyburn,
associate in Mathematics, is Chairman, has prepared a list of requirements which is less well-defined
than that of the Social Sciences.

The Johns Hopkins University
library has recently added to its
collection several volumes of particular interest, said Dr. John C.
French yesterday.
Chief among these is the manuscript constitution of the Liberal
Debating Club of Priceton ColIege. This gift, which the University received at the hands of
the late Dr. John H. Latane from
M rs. Hiram Woods, of Baltimore,
.is notable because of the fact the
club was organized and the document written by Woodrow Wilson, then a Princeton undergraduate. He was later to engage
in similar activities as a graduate student at Johns Hopkins.
Added To Page School Collection
Another is an addition to the
\Nalter Hines Page School of
International Relations called
Anthology of Verse of the Great
War, 1914-18, compiled by Marie
Conrad Lehr. The work consists
of three handsomely bound octavo
volumes in which the compiler
has pasted or copied in printed
script more than one thousand
poems evoked by the World War.
They have been collected "from
contemporaneous m a g a z i n e s,
weekly -penodicals, newspape-fs,
and current books"; they include
verse by Thomas Hardy, Rupert
Brooke, Joyce Kilmer;· Rudyard
Kipling, John Galsworthy, Carl
Sandburg, Lord Dunsany, John
Drinkwater, Gabriele d'Annunzie, and numerous others. It is
thought that the volumes will be
of considerable interest to students of the War.
The Friends of the Library
presented the library with a
beautifully printed and bound
copy of Chateaubriand's Atala and
Rene, published in 1805. This is
not the first edition of these
works but is the first edition of
the author's final revision, the
form of the works to which he
gave his approval.
Lafayette Book Gotten
A recent acquisition of the
Library is M_emoirs of Lafayette,
a volume which includes several
books setting forth letters, addresses, anecdotes, etc., dealing
with the French patriot. Each of
the books was published either in
the late eighteenth or early nineteenth century, and are of value
not only for their intrinsic worth
but also their scarcity, Dr. French
said. Among these is Voyage du
general Lafayette aux Etats-Unis
d' Ameriqiue, published in 1826,
which includes an account of Lafayette's visit to Baltimore.
The libraries of teh University
at Homewood contain over 310,000 bound volumes while the
Welch Medical Library contains
400,000 volumes. Of the Homewood collections the Law Institute has 15,000; Engineering, 11,000; the Page School, 2,000;
Geology, 14,000; Physics and
Mathematics, 6,700; Psy<)hology,
5,000; Chemistry, 6,500; Plant
Physiology, 1,000.

Doubtless, the plan, finally promulgated, after detailed study, in
December, 1931, will serve to raise
the standard of the A.B. school at
Homewood and to weed out those
undergraduates who attend college
to just "take courses." It will
call upon greater concentration
in and thought to a particular field.
It will necessitate the r.etaining o~

full years, to be used at the completion of the senior year in the

is to be the outstanding determining
factor for graduation.

Announcement of the requirements for graduation under the
New Plan was made last week by
Dean E. W. Berry, of the College
of Arts and Sciences. These requirements will affect all candidates
for the A.B. degree at the Hopkins.
It will be recalled that under the
New Plan, which is to be inaugurated next fall, a Sophomore, after
proving to the Bo,ard of Collegiate
Studies that he is qualified to remain in the College, must arrange
his courses in one of three groups:
the Social Science, Natural Science,
or Literature and Language. However, this applies ol.'ily to candidates
for the A.B. who have completed
the regular collegiate requirements
for tllillfllt and second years of
~~ - --~ --- ___
Groups Of Related Subjects

Each of the three groups is made
up of departments of related subjects. The Social Science Group
incudes the subjects of History,
_)olitical Economy, Political Science,
History of Philosophy, Ethics, and
Education; the Natural Sciences
comprise Biology, Chemistry, Geology, Mathematics, Physics, Psychology, and Logic; and the Literature and Language Group is made
up of the subjects of English,
Fren_ch, German, Italian, Spanish,
Latin, Greek, Hebrew, Sanskrit, and
Archaeology.
The purpose of
grouping related subjects into the
one unit, it was stated by Dr. W. S.
Holt, associate in American History, and Chairman of the Social
Science Group, is that the student's
knowledge may not be limited to the
specific subject in which he is interested, but that he may have a
general acquaintance with related·
fields of knowledge. In the Social
Science Group, one must prove his
familiarity with all the subjects in
the Group, at least generally, besides fulfilling his obligations to his
particular subject.
Before a student in the Social
Science Group may graduate, he
must take a comprehensive examination on the following points, which
are given as they will apear in the
1932-33 University Catalogue:
Group Requirements

A knowledge of economic
geography.
A knowledge of international
problems and organization in
modern times.
A knowledge of the principal
governments of the world, and
how they function.
An acquaintance with the more
important political and economic
theories of the past and present,
and of their historical setting.
A knowledge of modern European history.
A knowledge of the history of
the United States.
An appreciation of the methods of the social sciences.

A knowledge of the characteristics forms of the economic systems of the past ad present, of
the causes and consequences of
the economic development of the
United States.
The nature of this comprehensive
examination is ·an outline specifically indicating the points which the
student is to find out by research,
and he will be allowed four weeks
in which to complete the problem.
The first comprehensive will be
given in May, 1933.
It was
emphasised by Dr. Holt that these
reqttirements are those of the
Group alone. Each Department in
the Group may make its own specifications as to the knowledge of the
student, and may require that he
· ~.kt:i.mvf~dg~ ;
·
courses, research, reading, or by
any other method which it desires.
As far as the Group is concerned, it
makes no difference how the student
prepares for his comprehensive
exam, Dr. Holt declared. Furthermore, the exam, which is given each
year, may be taken regardless of
the number of years the student has
been in the college. Thus, especially industrious ones may graduate
after their Junior year.
Personal Research

This conception of the comprehensive examination is identical
with the idea of the term paper,
recently set forth by a local college,
insofar as it permits the student to
carry on a research of his subject on
his own account. The department
may require him to satisfy its
specifications either by examination
or any other means it may determine upon. He will be assigned to
a faculty adviser who will be able
to direct his method of approach to
the completion of his work.
A plan whereby classes would be
suspended for given periods of
possibly a month in duration, dur·

mg
wh.1c h time
t h e stu d ent wou ld
carry out a program of reading on
a subject assigned him and turn in
a report on his work, is under consideration by the Social Science
Group, Dr. Holt stated. He regards as a possible impediment to
the smoothness of this plan, however, the fact that instructors in all
the Groups may not be willing to
suspend their classes at the same
time, if at all. Having to attend any
classes would disturb an uninterrupted reading period and cause it
to lose its effectiveness, it is believed. It is hoped, however, that an
arrangement may be made for the
effecting of the idea.

which Dr. Gordon F. Whyburn,
associate in Mathematics, is Chairman, has prepared a list of requirements which is less well-defined

The Johns Hopkins University
library has recently added to its
collection several volumes of particular interest, said Dr. John C.
French yesterday.
Chief among these is the manuscript constitution of the Liberal
Debating Club of Priceton ColIege. This gift, which the University received at the hands of
the late Dr. John H. Latane from
M rs. Hiram Woods, of Baltimore,
.is notable because of the fact the
club was organized and the document written by Woodrow Wilson, then a Princeton undergraduate. He was later to engage
in similar activities as a graduate student at Johns Hopkins.
Added To Page School Collection
Another is an addition to the
\Nalter Hines Page School of
International Relations called
Anthology of Verse of the Great
War, 1914-18, compiled by Marie
Conrad Lehr. The work consists
of three handsomely bound octavo
volumes in which the compiler
has pasted or copied in printed
script more than one thousand
poems evoked by the World War.
They have been collected "from
contemporaneous m a g a z i n e s,
weekly -penodicals, newspape-fs,
and current books"; they include
verse by Thomas Hardy, Rupert
Brooke, Joyce Kilmer;· Rudyard
Kipling, John Galsworthy, Carl
Sandburg, Lord Dunsany, John
Drinkwater, Gabriele d'Annunzie, and numerous others. It is
thought that the volumes will be
of considerable interest to students of the War.
The Friends of the Library
presented the library with a
beautifully printed and bound
copy of Chateaubriand's Atala and
Rene, published in 1805. This is
not the first edition of these
works but is the first edition of
the author's final revision, the
form of the works to which he
gave his approval.
Lafayette Book Gotten
A recent acquisition of the
Library is M_emoirs of Lafayette,
a volume which includes several
books setting forth letters, addresses, anecdotes, etc., dealing
with the French patriot. Each of
the books was published either in
the late eighteenth or early nineteenth century, and are of value
not only for their intrinsic worth
but also their scarcity, Dr. French
said. Among these is Voyage du
general Lafayette aux Etats-Unis
d' Ameriqiue, published in 1826,
which includes an account of Lafayette's visit to Baltimore.
The libraries of teh University
at Homewood contain over 310,000 bound volumes while the
Welch Medical Library contains
400,000 volumes. Of the Homewood collections the Law Institute has 15,000; Engineering, 11,000; the Page School, 2,000;
Geology, 14,000; Physics and
Mathematics, 6,700; Psy<)hology,
5,000; Chemistry, 6,500; Plant
Physiology, 1,000.

spoken at practically every college
and university in the United States,
and has campaigned for the Labor
Party in England. Originally, he
was in the ministry, but later withdrew from this profession, in order

freely. Mr. Wilson is a graduate
